title: extensis suitcase | sets advice - divide
content:

I am new to this program and I am wondering does anyone have ideas dividing fonts in sets,  
beside regular serif and sans divison.

I tought dividing it to classical ones ( helvetica, frutiger, univers... for example) and modern ones...

comments.content:
Hi gardenize,

Our corporation uses Suitcase. Our experience has been that the less fonts loaded in Suitcase, the better.

We create our sets by project. For instance, when I’m working on a brochure, I create a folder on my hard drive that contains only the fonts used in the brochure and name the folder: brochure fonts. I load that folder into Suitcase, where it becomes a set, and activate it while I’m working on the brochure. When I’m done, I pull the set out and Suitcase is empty (except for system fonts) again.

The advantage to this method is that all fonts must be deliberately added to a project, rather than automatically opening via Suitcase. This may not be a preferred method for your organization.

Kristin

I use Font Explorer but it must be similar. My sets are:

antique/distressed  
calligraphic/uncial  
classic serif w/expert  
condensed - this is both for sans and serif fonts  
cool (this one is way subjective!)  
dingbats  
display/initial caps  
funny  
grunge  
handwriting  
nouveau/deco  
retro (mostly 50s style here)  
sans  
script  
slab  
techno

I also have a few sets for foundries. But my basic purpose for sets is to browse the categories. Unlike Kristin, I keep all my fonts loaded in Font Explorer so having the sets avoids my needing to scroll thru literally thousands of fonts to find something that grabs me. It took awhile to set all this up but then it’s a snap to maintain - when I add a new font I just dump it into the relevant category(s).

I used to create job or project sets, but since Font Explorer activates automatically when you open a file, that doesn’t seem necessary anymore.

Sandro, the history of writing has still to be written, you are aware of that, you are not “new to a program,” you are new to typography, which is a wonderful thing, and the reason why Typophile exists, I think.

:). I not new to typography. I am new to the program. I am in search of useful and fast use of typesets. So apart from regular serif, sans, I think of other way of making and using sets efficiently, for example how much I am using some particular font ( gotham, din for example), then for example classics (including both serifs and sans - garamond and  
helvetica for example - historical value of course), somethin modern or something like that...

Of course study of any new particular work is essential,
Okay, sorry, I have never used Suitcase, I suppose it is easy then to create subsets/groups of font files to activate/deactivate based on job, Vox, Novarese, foundry, color, script style, &c.
